intro: Chamaesyce polycarpa var. hirtella, commonly known as the hairy false nettle, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its hairy, alternate leaves that are often glandular and slightly succulent. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers in clusters, which are surrounded by modified leaves called cyathia. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its botanical features make it identifiable by its dense pubescence and unique floral structure.
